courseDescription: An introduction to basic concepts, methods and issues in philosophy, and a consideration of representative types of philosophical thought concerning human nature, the world, knowledge, and value.

A study of the principles of correct reasoning and the types of fallacious reasoning.  Includes an examination of the philosophical and historical context of logic, and the application of logical methods to philosophical questions.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying logical methods to philosophical questions

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  An Honors version of PHIL 150P.

What is the meaning of life, and what role might the end of life play in living meaningfully? This course provides an introduction to philosophy and religious studies through an investigation of different views on death and the meaning of life from diverse cultures and identities. (Cross-listed with REL 150P)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of philosophical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of philosophical and religious texts

courseDescription: What ways of thinking, feeling, and acting are essentially human? This course focuses on some of the most influential and fascinating philosophical and religious accounts of human nature from diverse cultural perspectives. Topics may include the nature of human beings in relation to God, society, ethics, politics, knowledge, the environment, freedom, evolution, the mind, language, race, gender, and technology. (Cross-listed with REL 155E)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and interpreting diverse cultural perspectives
Effective communication of philosophical and religious concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of philosophical and religious accounts of human nature
Analyzing the relationship between human beings and various aspects such as God, society, politics, knowledge, environment, freedom, evolution, mind, language, race, gender, and technology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and presenting complex philosophical ideas
Leading discussions on sensitive topics such as race, gender, and religion

courseDescription: This course provides training in how to speak up in defense of moral concerns in a STEM organizational context, and how to do so in an effective and productive way.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing moral dilemmas in STEM fields

courseDescription: This course is the study abroad equivalent of PHIL 110P, an introduction to basic concepts, methods and issues in philosophy, and a consideration of representative types of philosophical thought concerning human nature, the world, knowledge, and value.

This course provides an in-depth introduction to information literacy from library and information science, information ethics, and computer science perspectives along with applications to cybersecurity research and professional activity. This course is aligned with Old Dominion University’s general education learning outcomes for information literacy.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving related to information ethics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Alignment with general education learning outcomes
Organizing information in a cybersecurity context

courseTitle: Honors: World Religions: Beliefs and Values
courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  A special Honors section of PHIL 250E.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of religious beliefs and values
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of religious texts and beliefs

courseDescription: An introduction to the study of ethics through philosophical reflection on a variety of moral issues of contemporary significance.  Topics covered will vary by semester and instructor, and may include issues drawn from professional fields such as business, medicine, and information technology, plus matters of public concern like the environment, the treatment of animals, the use of military force, social justice, and civil and human rights.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ethical issues in information technology
Familiarity with ethical challenges in business and medicine
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Making ethical decisions in a leadership role

courseDescription: Is love universal or culturally bound? Is sexual desire biologically driven or learned? This course provides an introduction to Philosophy and Religious Studies through an investigation of love, sex, and desire vis-a-vis ethical values and societal norms.  (Cross-listed with REL 235E)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of societal norms and ethical values
Investigative research into cultural and biological factors of love and desire
Evaluation of philosophical and religious perspectives

courseTitle: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
courseDescription: A survey of philosophical problems common to the sciences, including an analysis of key concepts and an examination of science in its historical and cultural context.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Examination of scientific history and culture

courseDescription: A comparative and philosophical study of major world religions in the Eastern and Western traditions with particular attention being paid to their views about the basis of right action and the nature of good and evil.  Other points of comparison include the foundations of religious knowledge and belief, the meaning of human life, divinity, and death and immortality.

What is truth? How do we know when something is real or fake? Are you certain that other people perceive the world in the same way you do? In this course we’ll try to answer questions like these and more through an exploration of the relationship between our minds, our bodies, and the world around us.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and understanding of differing perspectives

courseDescription: This course provides practical training in information access, critical information assessment, and ethical information use in a theoretically-oriented research context, as well as a theoretical exploration of issues in information literacy, the ethics and politics of online informational spaces, and the philosophy of digital culture.
A study of selected topics designed for non-majors. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.

Metaphysics is the study of the ultimate nature of reality and epistemology is the study of what we can know about reality. This introduction to metaphysics and epistemology will engage with views of what exists and how we can know about it from a diverse collection of traditions and figures.

An examination of the philosophical foundations of ethical inquiry from a diverse collection of traditions and figures, including historically marginalized voices. Various ethical systems are considered, and different views of metaethics and moral psychology may be as well.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Respect for diversity and inclusivity in ethical discourse

courseDescription: A philosophical examination of ethical issues that arise in business and commerce.  Topics discussed will vary by semester and instructor, but may include affirmative action, ethical versus unethical sales and marketing techniques, the obligations of business to society (if any), and the moral foundations of capitalism.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of ethical issues in business
Analysis of ethical versus unethical sales and marketing techniques
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying affirmative action policies

courseDescription: An analytical and critical consideration of the philosophical foundations of religion.  Such topics as the existence of God, the problem of evil, theism and atheism, prayer, and immortality are discussed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the context of philosophical dilemmas
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Making informed judgments on complex philosophical issues

courseDescription: This course is a study of the thought of the classical Greek philosophers from the sixth century B.C.E. to the fifth century C.E.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of philosophical theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking and interpretation of ancient texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management and prioritization of reading material

courseDescription: This course is a survey of the rise of modern philosophy in the 17th and early 18th centuries in Europe.

This course examines the significant contributions of medieval philosophers to the development of philosophy of religion as well as other fields, including philosophy of language, logic, and ethics. Students examine the writings of medieval philosophers from Jewish, Christian, and Islamic traditions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of philosophical language and terminology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of different philosophical views
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Development and articulation of philosophical arguments

courseDescription: This course is a survey of modern philosophy in the 18th and 19th centuries in Europe, addressing figures such as Kant, Hegel, Schopenhauer, Marx, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche.

A study of the basic concepts and methods of logic as they occur in ordinary language, formal logical arguments, and an elementary logical system.  Traditional Logic is emphasized, but some elements of Modern Logic are also introduced.
Technical and Digital Skills: Introduction to elements of Modern Logic

courseDescription: An examination of the nature and basis of human obligations for the welfare of the environment with special attention to the foundations of ethical decision making.
An examination of the philosophical foundations of ethical decision making in biology, medicine, and the life sciences.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing ethical dilemmas in biology and medicine
Applying ethical frameworks to real-world scenarios

courseDescription: This course introduces students to several key religious traditions originating in Asia, such as Hindu traditions in India; Confucianism, Daoism, and popular religion in China, Buddhism and Shinto in Japan; and Buddhist traditions of China, Tibet, and Mongolia. Students will read and analyze primary sources in English translation. By examining artifacts from literature, art, and poetry, students will also learn about cultural history. Throughout the course, students will employ hermeneutical methods in the field of religious studies, such as methods of comparisons.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and analysis of religious texts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of religious and cultural texts

courseDescription: This course examines ethical issues relevant to computing and information technology, including: privacy; freedom of speech and content control on the Internet; individual and social responsibility; cybersecurity; cybercrimes; social impact of computers and other digital technologies; and ethical obligations of IT professionals.  Students will gain a broad understanding of central issues in cyberethics and the ways that fundamental ethical theories relate to these core issues.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing ethical issues related to IT
Discussing social impact of computers and digital technologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating individual and social responsibilities in IT
Understanding ethical obligations of IT professionals

courseDescription: This course explores, from a philosophical perspective, ethical questions arising from collecting, drawing inferences from, and acting on data, especially when these activities are automated and on a large scale. This course will provide students a framework for considering the ethical implications of data usage. Emphasis will be placed on discussing how historic and contemporary examples of potentially unethical practice could be altered to reduce harm and increase equity. Topics to be covered may include, but are not limited to, systematic approaches to assessing ethical issues; privacy and confidentiality; defining research and the responsibilities associated with conducting ethical research; implicit and structural biases in data collection and analysis; freedom of speech; and consent to data collection.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of data privacy and confidentiality
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on ethical issues
Communicating complex issues related to data ethics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Systematic approaches to assessing ethical issues
Identifying and addressing implicit and structural biases in data collection and analysis
Evaluating ethical implications of data usage

courseDescription: This course is a survey introduction to major African-American philosophical thinkers and  will address themes such as: What is the nature of race, and what is the nature of racism? What is the nature of the good? What does the good life look like, how should we make sense of beauty, and are those values different for each of us? And how should we make sense of social and civil life and of social and civic obligations in the context of deep and persisting injustice?
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding the nature of complex societal issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promoting inclusion and diversity in philosophical discussions

courseDescription: This course will draw on historical and contemporary scholarship to explore the evolution of the concept of race in relation to different theories of power. Topics may include how to define race, how people are racialized, genocide and social death, the use of racial epithets, cultural appropriation, ally-ship, and the role of activism.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical and contemporary racial theories
Critical thinking in relation to genocide and social death
Analysis of the role of activism

courseDescription: A structured work experience using analytical, research, and communication training from philosophy in a relevant industry, such as law, tech, finance, libraries, or in the public or nonprofit sectors. May be paid or unpaid. Criteria for evaluation will be determined by work supervisor and cooperating faculty advisor. May be repeated for credit. Available for pass/fail grading only.

The course offers three forms of practical experience for philosophy majors:  Professional (for students anticipating careers in relevant professions, including philosophy);  Classroom (for students anticipating graduate study and a teaching career); Civic/Social Affairs (for students interested in grassroots activism).  Consult the department for details and certain specific prerequisites.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in academic and professional settings

courseDescription: An intensive study of the basic teachings of Hinduism as manifested in its sacred writings.
A study of the origin, historical development, and contemporary status of Buddhism, in terms of its religious and philosophical elements and its influence in Asian cultures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital resources for historical and cultural study
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of philosophical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of religious and philosophical elements

courseDescription: This course engages in a critical exploration of what technology is as a human practice and how it develops over time in ways that influence and are influenced by society, culture, and human values. Students will also learn responsible, inclusive, and creative design and development practices through an understanding of how social structures are embedded in technology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of how social structures are embedded in technology
Knowledge of responsible, inclusive, and creative design and development practices
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Exploration and discussion of how technology influences society and culture
Discussion and debate on human values in technology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical exploration of technology as a human practice
Understanding and analysis of technology's development over time
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Responsible and inclusive design and development
Creative leadership in technology development and design

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.

A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.

An examination of the metaphysical, aesthetic, and ethical philosophical issues that accompany the creation, play, and critique of video games. Students will learn and analyze theories about what games are. They will think about and discuss the aesthetic qualities of video games and critically engage with attempts to fit video games into the larger art world. Students will engage with moral issues that arise from creating and consuming video games with morally problematic content. Finally, students will learn how to think critically about and interpret larger philosophical problems raised by video games and their themes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Interpretation of video games and their themes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of aesthetic qualities of video games
Engagement in moral debates around video games
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of philosophical theories about games
Critical engagement with attempts to fit video games into the larger art world
Critical thinking about philosophical problems raised by video games

courseDescription: A philosophical survey of approaches to understanding gender and gender differences. The course will also serve as an introduction to feminist philosophy, with a particular emphasis on feminist ethics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and Respect for Diverse Perspectives

courseDescription: This course is an examination of the writings of some of the major philosophers in the Existentialist and Phenomenology movements of the 19th and 20th centuries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical and contemporary philosophical literature

courseDescription: This course is an examination of the writings of some of the major American philosophers in the Pragmatist tradition.

courseTitle: Language and Thought: History of Analytic Philosophy
courseDescription: This course is a study of the history of the Analytic tradition in philosophy up through the 20th century.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking and evaluation of philosophical theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for complete reading and research

courseDescription: A philosophical analysis of the relation between man, society, and the state, studying about a dozen philosophers since Plato on such topics as justice, authority, law, freedom, and civil rights.
This course is an examination of intellectual currents in postmodernism and post-structuralism as they pertain to central questions in social and political thought.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying postmodern and post-structural perspectives to social and political issues
Critical thinking and interpretation of complex ideas

courseDescription: An examination of the nature of law and philosophical issues concerning the law.

Considers the relationship of philosophy and education.  Topics considered include:  philosophy as a foundation for education, education as an institution, and educational and philosophical issues as they relate to each other.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of philosophical principles in education

courseDescription: An examination of philosophical issues surrounding the practice of work.  Topics to be discussed may include the definition of work, alienation, exploitation, whether there is a right to work or a right not to work, religious perspectives on work, and gender issues in work.
This course is an examination of the philosophical writings of Hume and Kant and their influence.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear articulation of complex philosophical theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of Kant and Hume's theories

courseDescription: This course is an examination of the philosophical writings of Hegel and Marx and their influence.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of philosophical ideas

courseDescription: This course is an examination of Nietzsche’s attempt to provide a life-affirming philosophy after laying waste to many traditional Western efforts to find life meaningful.

This course provides students with a problem-oriented, critical, and comparative understanding of problems in contemporary epistemology.  Topics include skepticism and responses thereto, analyses of knowledge, the externalist versus internalist debate, foundationalism and coherentism, and social approaches to knowledge including contextualism and feminism.
An examination of various ways in which the mind has been understood in philosophy and in psychology and of the methods that have been used in the study of the mind.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research methods in philosophy and psychology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparing different philosophical and psychological perspectives

courseDescription: A study of the concepts and philosophical problems in the sciences:  scientific reasoning, confirmation, explanation, laws, meaning, theories, revolutions, progress, and values.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Appreciating the progress and evolution of scientific disciplines
Assessing the value and impact of scientific discoveries

courseDescription: An intensive examination of ethical issues in a particular field or profession; an emphasis on ethical theory underlying practical decisions.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of ethical theory to practical decisions

courseDescription: This course will provide students with an introduction to Native American philosophies with a focus on issues of identity, genocide, personhood, gender, sovereignty, and decolonization. Topics will be approached though a consideration of Native American philosophical methodologies and Native views regarding metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics. (Cross-listed with REL 451)
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of online databases for academic research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on philosophical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of metaphysical, epistemological, and ethical concepts
Understanding and interpreting historical events and their effects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on complex topics

courseDescription: A study of Chinese thought emphasizing Early and Classical Confucianism and Taoism, Chinese Buddhism, and NeoConfucianism.  Modern currents of Chinese thought is also discussed.
A study of the religious and philosophical traditions of Japan.  Emphasis will be given to Shintoism, Buddhism, and Neo-Confucianism and their contemporary status and influence in Japanese culture.
Intensive examination of the thought of one major philosopher or philosophical movement.  This is a writing intensive course.

The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Philosophy
courseDescription: Independent reading and study of a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Philosophy

Students will learn and analyze theories about what games are. They will think about and discuss the aesthetic qualities of video games and critically engage with attempts to fit video games into the larger art world. Students will engage with moral issues that arise from creating and consuming video games with morally problematic content. Finally, students will learn how to think critically about and interpret larger philosophical problems raised by video games and their themes.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of philosophical theories

courseDescription: A philosophical survey of approaches to understanding gender and gender differences. The course will also serve as an introduction to feminist philosophy, with a particular emphasis on feminist ethics.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of theories on gender differences
Applying feminist ethics to real-world situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading respectful discussions on sensitive topics

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of modernist and postmodernist thought

courseDescription: An examination of the nature of law and philosophical issues concerning the law.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical reading of philosophical and legal texts
Critical thinking and analysis of legal principles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing thoughts and arguments in a coherent manner

courseDescription: Considers the relationship of philosophy and education.  Topics considered include:  philosophy as a foundation for education, education as an institution, and educational and philosophical issues as they relate to each other.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Formulating educational strategies based on philosophical principles
Aligning educational practices with philosophical foundations

courseDescription: An examination of philosophical issues surrounding the practice of work. Topics to be discussed may include the definition of work, alienation, exploitation, whether there is a right to work or a right not to work, religious perspectives on work, and gender issues in work.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and discussing various perspectives on work
Engaging in respectful debate on sensitive topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of societal norms and beliefs about work
Problem-solving in the context of philosophical dilemmas
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the impact of work structures on individuals and society
Applying philosophical insights to leadership and organizational decisions

courseDescription: This course is an examination of the philosophical writings of Hume and Kant and their influence.
This course is an examination of the philosophical writings of Hegel and Marx and their influence

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation and understanding of Nietzschean philosophy
Comparative analysis of different philosophical approaches

courseTitle: Studies in the Philosophy of Art
courseDescription: An evaluation of the field of art in relation to the rest of human culture, emphasizing the various approaches that may be used.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the relationship between art and human culture

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualifies students to work in subjects of mutual interest that, die to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.

A seminar providing foundations for and experience in the critical examination of technologies and their human and social impact. Topics will vary and may include AI, innovation, social media, robotics, healthcare, gaming, art, and music.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to articulate the human and social impact of technologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to assess the impact of technologies on society
Analyzing the implications of AI and robotics
Evaluating the role of social media in society
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on technology and humanities
Organizing thoughts on complex technological issues

courseDescription: An investigation of ethical issues in public health policy, practice, and research.  Students will develop a capacity for reasoned judgments in these matters by understanding and applying basic moral concepts, theories, and ideals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of Moral Concepts in Public Health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of Ethical Issues in Public Health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of Ethical Theories and Ideals

courseDescription: A philosophical study of rights applicable to the international arena.  Theories from the early Modern European period to the present day will be treated.  Coverage includes international law, the rights of nations, and human rights.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of historical and modern theories of rights
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of different rights theories
Effective communication of complex philosophical ideas
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and contemporary theories
Critical evaluation of international rights and laws
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the structure of international governance
Leading discussions on human rights and national rights

courseDescription: The advanced study of special topics that may not be offered regularly.
Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and synthesis of philosophical texts

courseDescription: A seminar providing foundations for and experience in the critical examination of technologies and their human and social impact. Topics will vary and may include AI, innovation, social media, robotics, healthcare, gaming, art, and music.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of technology impact
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of human and social impact
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and leading discussions on various technology topics

courseDescription: An investigation of ethical issues in public health policy, practice, and research.  Students will develop a capacity for reasoned judgments in these matters by understanding and applying basic moral concepts, theories, and ideals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research and analysis of public health policies
Understanding and application of moral theories and concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Making reasoned judgments in public health matters
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing ethical dilemmas in public health
Applying moral concepts to solve ethical issues

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and contemporary rights theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex international rights issues
